G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: The Superior Court has subject matter jurisdiction pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 4, because the amount in controversy, including medical expenses, lost wages, and pain and suffering, exceeds $25,000, exclusive of interest and costs.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 2, and 9.proposition: Venue is proper in Berkshire County under G.L. c. 223, §§ 1, 2, and 9 because the events and occurrences giving rise to this claim took place in Pittsfield, Berkshire County, Massachusetts, and Defendant resides in Berkshire County.

Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148, 154.proposition: Even if the dangerous condition of the tree branch were considered open and obvious, Defendant’s duty of reasonable care extended to taking steps to eliminate or guard against that danger where, as here, Defendant reasonably should have anticipated that lawful users of the sidewalk would proceed to walk under the branch and could not avoid it without undue burden or risk.
Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148, 154.support_reasoning: The case clearly holds that a landowner’s duty of reasonable care can include a duty to remedy or guard against an open and obvious danger when the landowner should anticipate that lawful entrants will nonetheless encounter it. However, Dos Santos deals with a trampoline–pool setup on residential property, not with a tree branch or sidewalk context, and it does not discuss the inability to avoid the condition without undue burden or risk in the way the proposition frames it. The accurate takeaway is the broader § 343A duty-to-remedy principle, not the specific sidewalk/tree-branch scenario described.
Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148, 154.relevant_excerpt: “A landowner, though, ‘is not relieved from remedying an open and obvious danger where [the landowner] “can and should anticipate that the dangerous condition will cause physical harm to the [lawful visitor] notwithstanding its known or obvious danger.”’ Papadopoulos, supra, quoting Soederberg… Section 343A thus instructs that… a landowner is not relieved from remedying that danger where he knows or has reason to know that lawful entrants may not heed the warning for a variety of reasons, including their own failure to exercise reasonable care.” (465 Mass. at 154–58).

Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..proposition: Even if the dangerous condition of the tree branch were considered open and obvious, Defendant’s duty of reasonable care extended to taking steps to eliminate or guard against that danger where, as here, Defendant reasonably should have anticipated that lawful users of the sidewalk would proceed to walk under the branch and could not avoid it without undue burden or risk.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly discusses the open and obvious danger doctrine and adopts Restatement (Second) of Torts § 343A, stating that a property owner is not relieved from remedying an open and obvious danger when it can and should anticipate that lawful visitors will proceed to encounter it. The court gives the specific example of snow or ice on a walkway that people would reasonably continue to cross rather than turn back, which matches the proposition’s point that the duty of reasonable care may require eliminating or guarding against even open and obvious hazards when avoiding them would impose undue burden or risk.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “A property owner, however, is not relieved from remedying an open and obvious danger where it ‘can and should anticipate that the dangerous condition will cause physical harm to the [lawful visitor] notwithstanding its known or obvious danger.’ Soederberg v. Concord Greene Condominium Ass’n, 76 Mass. App. Ct. 333, 338 (2010), quoting Restatement (Second) of Torts § 343A comment f, at 220 (1965). ‘[O]ne of the specific circumstances where harm to others is foreseeable is where the [property owner] has reason to expect that the [lawful visitor] will proceed to encounter the known or obvious danger….’ … It is not reasonable for a property owner to leave snow or ice on a walkway where it is reasonable to expect that a … visitor would choose to risk crossing the snow or ice rather than turn back or attempt an equally or more perilous walk around it.”}

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707\u2.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, landowners and persons in control of real property owe a duty to all lawful entrants, including pedestrians using adjacent public ways who are foreseeably exposed to conditions on the land, to exercise reasonable care to maintain their property in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707\u2.support_reasoning: The provided excerpt is a concurrence by Justice Kaplan criticizing the continued reliance on the trespasser/licensee/invitee distinctions; it does not address duties to pedestrians on adjacent public ways or articulate the scope of a landowner’s duty to all lawful entrants. While the main Mounsey opinion does abolish the licensee/invitee distinction and move toward a general reasonable-care standard to lawful entrants, nothing in this quoted concurring text states or applies a duty to pedestrians using adjacent public ways. On the basis of the excerpt alone, the case does not clearly support the specific proposition claimed.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707\u2.relevant_excerpt: "The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a ‘licensee’ rather than an ‘invitee,’ or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors. But footnote 7 seems to say that ‘trespassers’ stand apart, that that characterization is to remain decisive or highly influential."

Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739,.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, landowners and persons in control of real property owe a duty to all lawful entrants, including pedestrians using adjacent public ways who are foreseeably exposed to conditions on the land, to exercise reasonable care to maintain their property in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances.
Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739,.support_reasoning: The opinion does restate the general Massachusetts rule that landowners owe a duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors and to exercise reasonable care in the use of their land so as not to injure travelers on adjacent highways. But the holding squarely rejects extending that duty to require a landowner to provide safe passage across or make safety alterations to an adjacent public highway, even where pedestrians foreseeably cross between the landowner’s lots. Thus, while it affirms a limited duty regarding conditions on the land, it does not support the broader proposition stated and in fact cautions against expanding such duties to adjacent public ways.
Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739,.relevant_excerpt: “It is well established that an owner or possessor of land owes a common law duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors… This duty includes an obligation to maintain the premises in reasonably safe condition… Although a landowner or possessor typically is not held to any duty with respect to public highways adjacent to or crossing his land, he must exercise reasonable care in the use of his land so as not to injure a traveler on the highway.… To hold that Westwood owed the plaintiff such a duty would significantly expand the scope of a landowner or possessor’s duties with respect to adjacent public roads….”

Blood v. Dewey, 210 Mass. 62, 64\u201365.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, landowners and persons in control of real property owe a duty to all lawful entrants, including pedestrians using adjacent public ways who are foreseeably exposed to conditions on the land, to exercise reasonable care to maintain their property in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances.
Blood v. Dewey, 210 Mass. 62, 64\u201365.support_reasoning: The opinion deals entirely with landlord–tenant law, specifically whether a tenancy at will was terminated, whether statutory notice was waived, and whether the defendants remained liable for rent. It does not address duties of landowners or persons in control of real property to lawful entrants or to pedestrians on adjacent public ways, nor any standard of reasonable care in maintaining premises. Accordingly, it does not provide authority for the tort duty proposition stated.
Blood v. Dewey, 210 Mass. 62, 64\u201365.relevant_excerpt: "We are constrained to hold that the tenancy at will was not terminated and that the defendants are liable for the rent declared on. The rulings requested were rightly refused. Talbot v. Whipple, 14 Allen, 177. Fifty Associates v. Grace, 125 Mass. 161, 163. Whicher v. Cottrell, 165 Mass. 351."

Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..proposition: This duty of reasonable care includes the obligation to remedy or reasonably protect against dangerous conditions on the property that pose a foreseeable risk of injury to persons lawfully on or immediately adjacent to the premises and to take reasonable steps to inspect for and correct such conditions.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states that property owners owe lawful visitors a duty of reasonable care that includes making reasonable efforts to protect them against dangerous conditions on the property, including snow and ice, which cause foreseeable harm. The court details that this duty covers both hazards on the premises and on walkways/parking areas used by lawful visitors, and frames it in terms of knowing or having reason to know of the risk and taking reasonable steps to protect against it. This aligns with the proposition’s description of a duty to remedy or protect against dangerous conditions posing foreseeable risks and to inspect and correct such conditions.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “If a property owner knows or reasonably should know of a dangerous condition on its property, whether arising from an accumulation of snow or ice, or rust on a railing, or a discarded banana peel, the property owner owes a duty to lawful visitors to make reasonable efforts to protect lawful visitors against the danger.” (457 Mass. at 383)

Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 147\u20134.proposition: This duty of reasonable care includes the obligation to remedy or reasonably protect against dangerous conditions on the property that pose a foreseeable risk of injury to persons lawfully on or immediately adjacent to the premises and to take reasonable steps to inspect for and correct such conditions.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 147\u20134.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses a general duty of reasonable care and then recognizes, in this specific context, a homeowner’s duty to ensure that firearms stored on her premises are properly secured against access by a known violent, mentally unstable person with unsupervised access. It does not articulate a broad premises-liability rule about remedying or inspecting for dangerous conditions on property or “immediately adjacent” areas in general. The case is about negligent storage of firearms and foreseeability of third-party criminal acts, not a general landowner duty to inspect and correct all dangerous conditions on or near the premises.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 147\u20134.relevant_excerpt: “We have recognized that ‘[a]s a general principle of tort law, every actor has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid physical harm to others.’ … In the circumstances of this case, we conclude that a homeowner who permits guns to be stored on her property and allows unsupervised access to that property by a person known by her to have a history of violence and mental instability, has a duty of reasonable care to ensure that the guns are properly secured.”

Gage v. Westfield, 26 Mass. App. Ct. 681.raw_text: Gage v. Westfield, 26 Mass. App. Ct. 681, 683–85 (1989)
Gage v. Westfield, 26 Mass. App. Ct. 681.proposition: Defendant owed Plaintiff a duty to exercise reasonable care in the ownership, maintenance, inspection, and control of the maple tree and its limbs that extended over the public sidewalk adjacent to his Property.
Gage v. Westfield, 26 Mass. App. Ct. 681.support_reasoning: The case deals with a municipality’s potential duty as a landowner regarding dangers posed by adjacent railroad property, not with a private property owner’s duty concerning trees or limbs overhanging a public sidewalk. While the court briefly acknowledges that a landowner’s duty of reasonable care can extend beyond property boundaries, it applies that concept to a remote railroad hazard and ultimately finds no liability based on public-duty and discretionary-function principles. It does not discuss or establish any duty to inspect, maintain, or control trees or overhanging limbs adjacent to a sidewalk, so it does not support the specific proposition stated.
Gage v. Westfield, 26 Mass. App. Ct. 681.relevant_excerpt: “We agree with the plaintiffs that in some situations a landowner’s duty to exercise reasonable care does not terminate abruptly at the borders of his property but may extend to include a duty to take safety measures related to known dangers on adjacent property. See Polak v. Whitney, 21 Mass. App. Ct. 349, 351-352 (1985), and cases cited. Given the obviousness of the danger here, however, we doubt that a private landowner in the position of the city would be liable…”

Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.raw_text: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth., 363 Mass. 165, 167–68 (1973)
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.proposition: Defendant knew or, in the exercise of reasonable care, should have known that the large, cracked, and drooping branch overhanging the sidewalk was in a dangerous and defective condition and created an unreasonable risk of harm to foreseeable pedestrians, including Plaintiff.
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.case_name: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.support_reasoning: The case concerns a foreign substance on a subway stairway and whether there was sufficient evidence that it had been present long enough for the defendant, exercising reasonable care, to discover and remove it. While the court articulates a general duty of a premises owner to keep areas reasonably safe and to know or ought to know of dangers, it does not address trees, branches, or analogous structural/vegetation defects, nor does it involve an overhanging branch or sidewalk context. Thus, it does not specifically support the proposition about a large, cracked, drooping branch overhanging a sidewalk creating an unreasonable risk to pedestrians.
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.relevant_excerpt: “The obligation of one who controls business premises is to use due care to keep the premises provided for the use of its patrons in a reasonably safe condition, or at least to warn them of any dangers that might arise from such use, which are not likely to be known to them, and of which the defendant knows or ought to know.” 363 Mass. at 167.

Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermkts., Inc.,.raw_text: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermkts., Inc., 448 Mass. 780, 784–86 (2007)
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermkts., Inc.,.case_name: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermkts., Inc.,.support_reasoning: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. concerns premises liability in a grocery store slip-and-fall and the adoption of the mode-of-operation doctrine for self-service retail environments. It does not involve trees, branches, neighbor complaints, or a landowner’s actual knowledge from specific warnings about a discrete, long-standing hazard. While it discusses actual and constructive notice in the abstract, it does not provide authority for the specific proposition that a property owner had notice because neighbors warned him about a visibly compromised tree branch and he acknowledged needing to address it later.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermkts., Inc.,.relevant_excerpt: “Historically, Massachusetts has also followed the traditional approach governing premises liability… This court has thus held that premises liability attaches only if a store owner has actual or constructive notice of the existence of the dangerous condition, sufficient to allow time for the owner to remedy the condition. Gallagher v. Stop & Shop, Inc., 332 Mass. 560, 563 (1955).”

Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 37.raw_text: Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 376 Mass. 101, 105 (1978)
Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 37.proposition: The weather conditions on July 15, 2023, were typical of a summer thunderstorm in Massachusetts and did not constitute an extraordinary or unforeseeable “Act of God” that would break the chain of causation. Defendant’s negligence was a substantial factor in causing the branch to remain in a compromised condition until it failed during routine weather.
Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 37.support_reasoning: The case deals with foreseeability of intervening third‑party negligence (an intoxicated seaman driving an unsecured forklift) and whether that breaks the chain of causation. It does not address weather, Acts of God, or what constitutes ordinary versus extraordinary storm conditions. Using Jesionek to support a proposition about summer thunderstorms in Massachusetts and the Act of God doctrine mischaracterizes the opinion’s subject matter and holding.
Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 37.relevant_excerpt: “The general rule is that ‘[t]he act of a third person, intervening and contributing a condition necessary to the injurious effect of the original negligence, will not excuse the first wrongdoer, if such act ought to have been foreseen. The original negligence still remains a culpable and direct cause of the injury.’ … Under the facts of this case the jury would have been warranted in concluding that the actions of the seaman were foreseeable.”

Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696 (2.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a defendant is liable in negligence when the defendant owes a duty of care to the plaintiff, breaches that duty, and the breach proximately causes injury and damages to the plaintiff.
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696 (2.support_reasoning: The court explicitly states the elements the plaintiffs must prove in a negligence action: breach of a duty to use reasonable care, actual loss, and causation between the breach and the loss. This aligns with the proposition that negligence liability in Massachusetts requires a duty of care, breach, proximate causation, and resulting damages, even though the opinion focuses on the failure of proof on causation.
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696 (2.relevant_excerpt: With respect to each such claim, the plaintiffs bear the burden of proving that the defendant committed a breach of the duty to use reasonable care, that the plaintiffs suffered actual loss, and that the defendant’s negligence caused their loss. See Restatement (Second) of Torts § 281 (1965); J.R. Nolan & L.J. Sartorio, Tort Law § 204 (2d ed. 1989). Causation is an essential element of that proof.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: In any event, under G.L. c. 231, § 85, any causal negligence attributable to Plaintiff is less than the negligence of Defendant and therefore does not bar recovery, and Plaintiff’s damages should be reduced, if at all, only in proportion to any percentage of negligence found to be attributable to her.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Pre-judgment and post-judgment interest as allowed by law, including pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B;

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 60.proposition: Pursuant to Article 15 of the Massachusetts Declaration of Rights, G.L. c. 231, § 60, and Mass. R. Civ. P. 38, Plaintiff hereby demands a trial by jury on all issues so triable.
